w:r.w:t: The following documentation specifies the XML representation of mathematical text for OOXML. This shared ML is known as that Office Math Markup Language (OMML). Mathematical text represented by OMML includes but is not limited to: equations, expressions, formulas, matrices
other mathematical elements. The outermost OMML element of an instance of mathematical text in display mode is
, a math paragraph of one or more instances of mathematical text. Each instance of mathematical text inside the math paragraph is represented as a single
is a combination of mathematical runs (
) and objects or functions such as accents (
strikeBLTR (Border Box Strikethrough Bottom-Left to Top-Right)
strikeTLBR (Border Box Strikethrough Top-Left to Bottom-Right)
The following elements describe the contents of mathematical text.
This element specifies the accent function, consisting of a base and a combining diacritical mark. If
is omitted, the default accent is U+0302 (COMBINING CIRCUMFLEX ACCENT). [
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the properties of the Accent function. If
is omitted, the default accent character is U+0302 (COMBINING CIRCUMFLEX ACCENT). [
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the alignment property on the

object. It is utilized only when the box is designated as an operator emulator. When 1 or true, this operator emulator serves as an alignment point; that is, designated alignment points in other equations can be aligned with it.
When the element is absent, the default is for the parent structure to not be an alignment point.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default value of the val attribute is
meaning that this property’s parent structure is an alignment point.
: For example, the following equation uses the operator emulator as an alignment point:
Its XML representation is as follows:
Their associated XML representation is as follows:

The subtraction symbols in each of the above equations have been identified as alignment points, so the equations are aligned at their subtraction symbols (because they are in the same Math paragraph).
Specifies a binary value for the property defined by the parent XML element.
specifies that the property shall be explicitly applied. This is the default value for this attribute and is implied when the parent element is present.
specifies that the property shall be explicitly turned off. This is implied when the parent element is not present.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the alignment of scripts in the subscript/superscript function. When 1 or true, subscripts and superscripts are aligned to each other. When 0 or false, they are kerned to the shape of the base. If this element is omitted, scripts are not aligned. In other words, when the element is absent, the default is for the
object to not align the superscript and subscript with each other.
When the element is present and the
attribute is absent, the default value of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.
The XML representation of the second example above is:
Specifies a binary value for the property defined by the parent XML element.
that the property shall be explicitly applied. This is the default value for this attribute and is implied when the parent element is present.
that the property shall be explicitly turned off. This is implied when the parent element is not present.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies any properties of the math argument. [
attribute on the base element of a
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the size, or script level, of an argument. If the element is omitted, the default argument size is 0.
Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default value of the val attribute is always
. However, this property does not specify an absolute size, rather it’s absolute to its starting size. Most arguments begin at the normal size which will be defined as
in the list below, but some begin, by default smaller or larger than the normal size. For instance,
represents that it is one size larger than normal,
represents that it is two sizes larger than normal,
represents that it is one size smaller than normal

represents that it is two sizes smaller than normal. The list below indicates the default starting sizes for each argument, if it is not in this list, then the size cannot be changed on that argument.
: The following example contains three runs: regular mathematical text,
with the base at script size
with the base at script-script size
Because the size is set to -1 on the degree argument, the degree argument is 1 size smaller normal.

Specifies a value between -2 and 2 for the property defined by the parent XML element. The positive or negative sign specifies in which direction to change argument size; the absolute value specifies by how much.
The table below represents two cases in which argument size can be changed:
has script-script size. Should the user wish for the
to be shown at script size, val should be set to +1 (that is, one size larger). Should the user wish for
to be shown at text size, val should be set to +2 (that is, two sizes larger).
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model (
This element specifies the bar function, consisting of a base argument and an overbar or underbar, as in
: The XML below demonstrates the overbar in use.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies properties of the bar function. If this element is omitted, the bar assumes its default location of top (the mathematical overbar).
(x with an underbar) is represented by the following XML representation:
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the justification of the matrix. Text outside of the matrix can be aligned with the bottom, top, or center of a matrix object. If this element is omitted, the matrix assumes center justification. In other words, whether the element is absent or present without the
The XML below represents the matrix with top
Because the matrix base justification is top, the top row of the matrix is lined up with the baseline of the rest of the line.
Specifies the vertical justification parent element respect to surrounding text. Possible values are
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the beginning, or opening, delimiter character. Mathematical delimiters are enclosing characters such as parentheses, brackets
braces. If this element is omitted, the default
'. In other words, when the element is absent, the default is for the delimiter object beginning character to be Unicode character U+0028 (LEFT PARENTHESIS).
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is empty which means the delimiter object beginning character is absent.
uses { and } as its enclosing characters:
Specifies the character used by the parent element. When it is omitted, the parent uses its assigned default.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the Border Box object, consisting of a border drawn around an instance of mathematical text (such as a formula or equation), as in
is omitted, then the default behavior of
is a rectangular border (as shown in the “abc” example below).
: The following example shows the XML representation of the following Border
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model (
This element specifies the properties of the Border Box object, which dictate the types of lines that can be drawn as part of the border. [Example:
(left and bottom edges) is represented by the following XML
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the box object, which is used to group components of an equation or other instance of mathematical text. A boxed object can (for example) serve as an operator emulator with or without an alignment point, serve as a line break point, have associated
, or be grouped such as not to allow line breaks within. If
is omitted, all properties will be “false” by default.
Its XML representation is as follows:
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies properties of the Box object, for example, whether the Box serves as operator emulator with or without an alignment point, serves as a line break point, or receives the correct spacing for the mathematical differential. [
is partly represented by the following XML:
The x is set to be an operator emulator, so it is given operator spacing around it.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies whether there is a line break at the start of a run, or at the start of the Box object, such that the line wraps at the start of the run or box object. These user-defined line breaks occur when the XML tag

is encountered and does not follow a mathematical "order of precedence". If this element is omitted, a manual break is not inserted. In other words, when the element is absent, the default is for the parent structure to not manually break onto the next line. When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property’s parent structure manually breaks onto the next line and is aligned with the beginning of the previous line.

The line may happen to wrap at this point if the mathematical text exceeds the column width. OMML does not specify behaviour for any kind of automatic line breaking. Instead, it delegates this functionality to the underlying rendering engine similarly to how it does with the choice of operator spacing and the determination of whether an operator is unary or binary.
: The following example includes a manual user-defined line break at the operator emulator:
There is a break on the == symbol so a manual line break occurs right before the == symbol.

Specifies the index of the operator on the previous line of mathematical text which shall be used as the alignment point for the current line of mathematical text . A line can be aligned to any operator on the previous line; this attribute specifies exactly which operator shall be the target of that alignment in cases where there are multiple operators. If
tag will align with the left margin of the first run of mathematical text.
: For example, consider the break in this instance of mathematical text:
The second line could theoretically be aligned to any of the four operators in the previous line.
value of 3 for the second line resolves this ambiguity; the second line is aligned to the third operator in the previous line.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies how binary operators are treated when they coincide with a line break. If this element is omitted, the line break occurs before the binary operator. That is, the binary operator is the first element on the wrapped line.
Whether the element is absent or present without the
The above examples demonstrate how such an equation would look depending on the value of the
document-property. These actual examples do not rely on the
property of this document to maintain their configurations. This would be impossible because the
property can only be set to one value for an entire document at any given time. Here we are demonstrating all three.
Specifies where to break on binary operators. Possible values are
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies how the subtraction operator is treated when it coincides with a line break, when
. If this element is omitted, the subtraction operator is repeated before and after the break.
Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is
Given the following XML representation using

Because the document option for break on binary subtraction is set to -+, any breaks in Math paragraphs on subtraction operators will display a – on the line before the break and a + on the line after the break.
Specifies how the subtraction operator is treated when it coincides with a line break, when

(Minimum Matrix Column Width) to determine the total Matrix Column Spacing (distance between the same edges of different columns). The following image depicts how

(or "Exactly"), then the unit is interpreted as points. If the rule is set to

This element specifies the character to be attached to the base of an accent object, a group character object, or an n-ary operator object. When the parent element is
value should be within the range of (U+0300–U+036F) or (U+20D0–U+20EF). When the parent element is
value should be a horizontal stretch character, such as U+2190 (LEFTWARD ARROW). When the parent element is
value should be an n-ary operator such as U+222B (INTEGRAL).
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is empty which means the corresponding objects character is absent.
If this property is omitted for
, the default accent character is U+0302 (ACCENT, COMBINING CIRCUMFLEX). If this property is omitted for
, the default character is U+23DF (BOTTOM CURLY BRACKET). If this property is omitted for
In other words, when the element is absent, the defaults are as follows:
accent object – Unicode character U+0302 (ACCENT, COMBINING CIRCUMFLEX)
group-character object – Unicode character U+23DF (BOTTOM CURLY BRACKET)
n-ary operator object – Unicode character U+222B (INTEGRAL)
: Examples of accent characters are the dot, hat
For example, the following XML represents the
Specifies the character used by the parent element. When it is omitted, the parent uses its assigned default.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the

This element specifies the number of columns to which a property applies.
Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is

Specifies the number of columns to which a column property applies.
specifies that the property applies to the next three columns of the matrix.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the

This element specifies the minimum column width of a matrix. The actual column width of a matrix will be the greater of either the width of the column’s widest argument or
. This additional spacing can be added to enhance appearance. If this element is omitted, the default minimum column width is
. Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is
gap spacing (also referred to as “Column Gap” or “Gap Width”) is added to the
(Minimum Matrix Column Width) to determine the total Matrix Column Spacing (distance between the same edges of different columns). The value of
is interpreted as twips (a twip is 1/20th of a point). Therefore, a spacing of
point will be set by a

(or "Exactly"), then the unit is interpreted as twips. If the rule is set to

This element specifies properties on control characters; that is, object characters that cannot be selected. Examples of control characters are n-ary operators (excluding their limits and bases), fraction bars (excluding the numerator and denominator)
allows formatting properties to be stored on these control characters. The control character inherits its formatting from the paragraph formatting;
contains the formatting differences between the control character and the paragraph formatting.
If this element is omitted, the character properties of the first control character are the same as the first character in the math object.
: The example below shows that the control character is of font Cambria Math. All other formatting, such as text size and color, are the same as the paragraph.

is also used to save properties on characters used in the built-down form of an instance of mathematical text that are not displayed in Professional form. For example, the mathematical text (in linear form) ∫_0^1 might have color on the _ or ^. Though these characters are not displayed in Professional form, their formatting is stored such that their formatting will roundtrip through build up and build down.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the delimiter object, consisting of opening and closing delimiters (such as parentheses, braces, brackets
an element contained inside. The delimiter may have more than one element, with a designated separator character between each element. [
Delimiter with more than one base and separators, whose XML is shown below:
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the default justification of display math, at the document level. Individual instances of mathematical text can overrule the default setting. If this element is omitted, the default justification is
. Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is
Display math can be left justified, right justified, centered, or centered as a group. When display math is centered as a group, the mathematical text is left aligned within a block
the entire block is centered with respect to column margins. If this element is omitted, the mathematical text is centered as a group. [
Specifies the default justification of mathematical text in the document. Possible values are
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the

: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This tag, which is an abbreviation for “element”, serves several functions (18 total) including that of the base argument of a mathematical object or function, the elements in an array
the elements in boxes. If all subelements are omitted, this element specifies the presence of an empty argument.
: The numerator of this function is an empty argument: .
: The tag was shortened to e to improve readability over “element”. “Element” was preferred over “Base” because “Element” sounded more neutral and appropriate to its multiple uses.
The following table shows the 18 different uses for e:
Argument to which the bar is applied
Argument around which the border box is drawn
Each instance of mathematical text in the single-column array
Math argument list of the function
Each element in the matrix row
n-ary and, e.g., integrand for an integral, summand for a summation
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the ending, or closing, delimiter character. Mathematical delimiters are enclosing characters such as parentheses, brackets
braces. If this element is omitted, the default
'. In other words, when the element is absent, the default is for the delimiter object beginning character to be Unicode character U+0029 (RIGHT PARENTHESIS).
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is empty which means the delimiter object beginning character is absent.
uses { and } as its enclosing characters:
Specifies the character used by the parent element. When it is omitted, the parent uses its assigned default.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by the
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the Array object (sometimes referred to as "Equation Array", despite its ability to hold mathematical text other than equations), an object consisting of one or more equations, expressions, or other mathematical text runs that can be vertically justified as a unit with respect to surrounding text on the line. Alignment of multiple points within each run of mathematical text can occur within the array through the use of align values and spacer values. An
is an ampersand within the array which acts as an alignment point (as described in §22.1.2.3). A

is an ampersand (represented by "&" in the example below) within the array which designates where space can be added in order to align the align values on different rows of the array. Within each argument in the array, every odd ampersand is an align value and every even ampersand is a spacer value (as well, the beginning of each argument provides an implied spacer value). If
is omitted, then the default values for its properties will be used. These defaults are:
<The character property of the first control character will be the character property of the first character in the
A more complex array with alignment points, e.g.:
digits of the sums line up properly, as the align values line up between each argument by adding space at the position of each spacer value.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the properties of the array object, including the vertical justification of the object and layout inside the object.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the fraction object, consisting of a numerator and denominator separated by a fraction bar. The fraction bar can be horizontal or diagonal, depending on the fraction properties. The fraction object is also used to represent the stack function, which places one element above another, with no fraction bar.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model (
This element specifies the name of the function in the Function-Apply object
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the properties of the fraction object

. Properties of the Fraction object include the type or style of the fraction. The fraction bar can be horizontal or diagonal, depending on the fraction properties. The fraction object is also used to represent the stack function, which places one element above another, with no fraction bar. [
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the Function-Apply object, which consists of a function name and an argument element (e) acted upon. It is often applied using a form of linear format. For example, in the linear format described in Unicode Technical Article #28, this object is applied by using the Function Application character (U+2061). [
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

that can be stored on the function apply object

This element specifies the Group-Character object, consisting of a character drawn above or below text, often with the purpose of visually grouping items.

This element specifies the growth property of n-ary operators. When 0 or false, n-ary operators such as integrals and summations do not grow to match the size of their operand height. When 1 or true, the n-ary operator grows vertically to match its operand height. If this property is omitted,
When the element is absent, the default value of the property when it is a child of a delimiter object is

(meaning that this property is not applied).

meaning that this property is applied.

This element specifies the document setting for the default placement of integral limits, when converted from a linear form to a two-dimensional output (professional form). Limits can be either centered above and below the integral, or positioned just to the right of the operator, as in:
When this integral object is written linearly, as
, the placement of limits is ambiguous.
is a document-level property that specifies the default positioning. When this element is omitted, the default placement of integral limits is

(that is, the location of subscripts and superscripts, or just to the right of the base or operator). Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is
: The XML that specifies this property in use is:
Specifies the default location of limits on the parent object. Possible values are

This element specifies the spacing between adjacent display math paragraphs, in twips. If this element is omitted, no spacing is applied between adjacent math paragraphs.
Specifies the value, in twips, of the parent element.

This element specifies justification of the math paragraph (a series of adjacent instances of mathematical text within the same paragraph). A math paragraph can be Left Justified, Right Justified, Centered, or Centered as Group. If this element is omitted, the math paragraph is Centered as Group. Whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is
. This means that the instances of mathematical text can be aligned with respect to each other, but the entire group of mathematical text is centered as a whole. [
: An example of Centered as Group is the following example, in which each equation is left-aligned, but the series is centered:

This element specifies the location of limits in n-ary operators. Limits can be either centered above and below the n-ary operator (shown in the first summation below) or positioned just to the right of the operator (shown in the second summation below).
When the element is absent, the default value of this property is ignored and the
(for all other n-ary operator objects) options are looked to for the limit placement.

This element specifies that the characters in the run are literal; that is, they are to be interpreted literally and not be built up based on any implied mathematical meaning. This is especially useful for operators or other special characters that signal a need for build up to an OMML reader. These characters are often encountered during a given instance of mathematical text when presented in a1-dimensional linear format, such as the linear format defined by Unicode Technical Note #28 (Sargent 2006).
When the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.
: In the following XML, the + operator is treated literally and does not receive proper binary spacing:

This element specifies the Matrix object, consisting of one or more elements laid out in one or more rows and one or more columns. It is important to note that matrices do not have built in delimiters. Like other math elements, matrices are contained in a delimiter object (§22.1.2.24) when delimiters are desired. Empty arguments (see §22.1.2.32) can be used to create gaps in matrices. The
tag (§22.1.2.83) can be used to indicate whether the empty arguments should be visible in the matrix (see the
are shown in the following table:
<The character property of the first control character shall be the character property of the first character in the m object >
<All columns will be vertically center aligned>

. Below is an example of a 2x2 matrix and its XML in its proper form (surrounding delimiters are not a property of the matrix and are only shown to demonstrate their relationship with a matrix. See the documentation for the
tag for XML examples of delimiters).
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies the default math font to be used in the document. If this element is omitted, font substitution (§17.8.2) should be used to determine the most appropriate font for use throughout the document.

Because the document option for Math font is set to the mathematically enabled font Cambria Math, Math is formatted with that font.
Specifies the default math font to be used in the document.

option is commonly used with the
option is used to expand the distribution of mathematical text within the bounds of an array while not impacting the Array Distribution itself.
element is omitted, Array Maximum Distribution is off. In other words, when the element is absent, the default value of the property is

This element specifies Array Object Distribution. When 1 or true, the contents of the array are spaced to the maximum width of the array object. When this element is omitted, the array does not receive object distribution. In other words, when the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.
is represented by the following XML:

Because object distribution and maximum distribution are applied, the equation array is expanded to fill the width that is allowed, and the columns are distributed horizontally within the object to the bounds of the object.

This element specifies an instance of mathematical text. When used independently (not inside an oMathPara) with non-mathematical text preceding and/or following it, an independent oMath
interpreted as an inline math zone. All such math zones, including equations, expressions, arrays of equations or expressions

formulas are represented by oMath blocks. When used in a display math zone (a math paragraph, oMathPara), oMath is a container for an instance of mathematical text that starts on its own line and is not an inline math zone. When an oMath block is part of a display math zone, it is not itself an inline math zone. When an oMath block is not part of a display math zone, it is interpreted as its own inline math zone. The contents of an oMath block do not differ between display zone containers and independent inline math zones.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies a math paragraph, or display math zone, that contains one or more oMath elements that are in display mode. The oMath containers of a display math zone are not themselves considered inline math zones.
is represented by the following XML:

This element specifies the Operator Emulator property on

. When 1 or true, the box and its contents behave as a single operator and inherit the properties of an operator. This means, for example, that the character can serve as a point for a line break and can be aligned to other operators. (For more details on the properties of an operator, see Unicode Technical Report #25, §3.2.2 and §3.2.3
Unicode Technical Note #28.) Operator Emulators are often used when one or more glyphs combine to form an operator, such as
When the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.

This element specifies the phantom object. This object has two primary uses: adding the spacing of the phantom base element
without displaying that base; and suppressing part of the glyph
: In the right column below, the descender of the
is suppressed (set to zero) while in the left column, it is shown. The presence or absence of the descender changes the shape of the

is the shape given in a particular typeface to a specific symbol. Most scripts share the notion of a baseline: an imaginary horizontal line on which characters rest. In some scripts, parts of glyphs lie below the baseline. The
spans the distance between the baseline
and the lowest descending glyph in a typeface
the part of a glyph that descends below the baseline has the name
spans the distance between the baseline and the top of the glyph that reaches farthest from the baseline.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies properties of the Phantom object, including whether the phantom is hidden or visible
the amount of space that is taken into account when laying out text and objects around phantoms.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model
This element specifies the Hide Placeholders property on a matrix

. When this property is on, placeholders do not appear in the matrix. If this element is omitted, placeholders do appear such that the locations where text can be inserted are made visible. In other words, when the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.

: The following two examples of matrices show the hidden (right matrix) and visible (left matrix) states of placeholders. The key difference between the placeholders in these matrices is that the left matrix contains visual representations for each placeholder in the matrix while the right matrix does not. However, the contents of each matrix remain the same between these two examples:

element does not specify how a placeholder should be visually represented. It only specifies whether placeholders should or should not be visualized. The above example (left) is only one possible visual representation.
In the matrix described by the XML below, placeholders will be hidden:

Specifies how white space should be handled for the contents of this element using the W3C space preservation rules. [
: Consider the following run contained within a WordprocessingML document:

Although there are three spaces on each side of the text content in the run, that whitespace has not been specifically marked as significant, therefore it is subject to the space preservation rules currently specified in that run's scope.
The possible values for this attribute are defined by §2.10 of the XML 1.0 specification.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this element’s content model

This element specifies that the phantom is transparent for spacing. This means that if the contents of the phantom are belonging to a special spacing class (such as binary operators, relational operators, differentials, etc.), the contents of that phantom are taken into consideration when laying out text. If transparency is turned off, then the contents of the phantom are ignored during layout. When this element is omitted, transparency is
. In other words, when the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.
In the following example, transparency is not applied on the phantom around the differential term.
. The spacing is incorrect. In the following integral, the only difference is that transparency is applied:

This element specifies the indent of the wrapped line of an instance of mathematical text. The line or lines of a wrapped instance of mathematical text after the line break can either be indented by a specified amount from the left margin, or right aligned. The default indent is 1". In other words, whether the element is absent or present without the val attribute, the default of the val attribute is

This element specifies the right justification of the wrapped line of an instance of mathematical text. The line or lines of a wrapped instance of mathematical text after the line break can either be indented by a specified amount from the left margin, or right aligned. If this element is present, the continuation is right aligned.
When the element is absent, the default value of the option is
meaning that this option is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this option is applied.

This element specifies that the phantom has zero width. The width of the contents of the phantom is not taken into account during layout. When this property is omitted, the phantom does have width (zero width is not applied).
When the element is absent, the default value of the property is
meaning that this property is not applied.
When the element is present and the val attribute is absent, the default of the val attribute is
meaning that this property is applied.

This is the complete list of simple types dedicated to Math.

This defines how to represent binary operators with respect to a line-wrapping break. The line can wrap before the operator or after the operator; alternately, the operator can appear both at the end of the first line and the beginning of the second.
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML Schema
This simple type is restricted to the values listed in the following table:
When line-wrapping breaks occur on binary operators, the binary operator appears after the break (at the start of the next line).
When line-wrapping breaks occur on binary operators, the binary operator appears before the break (at the end of the first line).
When line-wrapping breaks occur on binary operators, the binary operator appears on both sides of the break (at the end of the first line and the start of the next line).
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this simple type’s content model

This simple type specifies how to represent subtraction on both sides of a line-wrapping break, when the Break Binary Operators option is set to repeat. The first character represents the sign at the end of the line with the break; the second represents the sign at the start of the wrapped line. Options are --, -+
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML Schema
This simple type is restricted to the values listed in the following table:
Repetition of subtraction sign after a line-wrapping break is plus on the first line and minus on the second line.
Repetition of subtraction sign after a line-wrapping break is minus on the first line and plus on the second line.
Repetition of subtraction sign after a line-wrapping break is minus on the first and second lines.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this simple type’s content model
This Simple Type specifies the single character used by the parent element.
uses { and } as its enclosing characters, instead of the default ( and ).
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML
This simple type also specifies the following restrictions:

: The W3C XML Schema definition of this simple type’s content model

Fractions can be of type bar (horizontal fraction bar), skewed ("skw" - diagonal fraction bar with kerned and vertically adjusted numerator and denominator), linear ("lin" - diagonal fraction bar, takes up exactly one line of space)
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML
This simple type is restricted to the values listed in the following table:
Fraction with a horizontal fraction bar.
Fraction with slanted fraction bar, that takes up no
Stack object, which looks like a fraction with no fraction bar.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this simple type’s content model

This Simple Type specifies the justification of Math Paragraphs. Justification of the Math Paragraph can be Left, Right, Centered, or Centered as Group.
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML
This simple type is restricted to the values listed in the following table:
Centers each instance of mathematical text individually with respect to margins.
Justifies instances of mathematical text with respect to each other
centers the group of mathematical text (the Math Paragraph) with respect to the page.
: The W3C XML Schema definition of this simple type’s content model
Limits can be in one of two positions: Under-Over
- positioned to the side of the base, in the position of subscripts and superscripts).
This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML
This simple type is restricted to the values listed in the following table:
Limits placed to the side of the base, as opposed to directly over and under.
Limits placed to the directly above and below the base, as opposed to on the side.
